author: Jasper Hamill
title: Humans could evolve to become better looking - but more vulnerable to being wiped out by disease
text:
Evolution is set to make humans "smarter, stronger and better looking" over the next 1,000 years, researchers have claimed.
But although this future looks pretty, it could actually spell disaster for our species.
Humanity is likely to use genetic engineering or artificial intelligence to banish feared illnesses over the coming centuries, potentially cutting down on genetic diversity.
This could leave us vulnerable to being destroyed by just one terrifying disease which has evolved alongside us.
That's the claim from Youtube channel AsapScience , which has teamed up with National Geographic to produce a documentary showing what humans might look like in 1,000 years.
Humanity 2.0: Our species could look totally different in 1,000 years
These changes take thousands or hundreds of thousands of years," it said in a short video.
"Artificial intelligence or human-influenced changes will likely drive most of our evolution.
"We'll modify our babies' genes before birth to eliminate diseases they may carry or include desirable traits for our children.
"But while this may make us smarter, stronger and better looking, such genetic similarity or lack of human diversity leaves room for a single new disease of the future to wipe out the entire race."
It also predicted that humans would evolve dark skin to help protect from increased level of UV light due to the erosion of the ozone layer.
Family time: Could these be the sort of infection-prevention clothes end up being worn about the house?
We may also become taller and thinner to cope with increased global temperatures, because slender, long bodies are better at dissipating heat.
The number of languages spoken will probably diminish from 7,000 to less than 100.
Humans could also benefit from unexpected genetic mutations, perhaps allowing them to digest almost anything or see 100 times more colours than ordinary people.
Of course, all of this relies on managing not to kill each other - or be killed by disease or asteroid strike.
